columns.text: These set of questions will allow us to analyze what a sensitivity analysis is and its importance.

A sensitivity analysis is a method used to determine how some values of the firm will be affected based on the other variables being adjusted. This type of analysis allows the firm to run a simulation before making a significant financial decision.

**a.)** For this specific firm, we can start by measuring the best- and worst-case net present value when only the fixed cost is adjusted and all other parameters are kept constant. From this, we will be able to determine how sensitive the net present value is to the adjustment of fixed cost. 

After doing this, we can then try adjusting the variable cost instead of the fixed cost. 

Once these two are done, we can then compare which factor contributes more to the adjustment of the Net Present Value of the firm.

**b.)** From this type of analysis, we can determine which cost value, the fixed cost or the variable cost, needs to be adjusted in order to get a higher net present value. Being able to determine the optimal way to change these values allows us to build a healthy short-term and long-term financial status.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
